statement.text: Deep venous reconstruction encompasses endovascular and open surgical procedures to restore venous outflow (stenting, bypass) or valve competence (valvuloplasty, transplant) for severe post-thrombotic syndrome or primary deep venous insufficiency refractory to conservative therapy.
statement.formal: Deep_Venous_Reconstruction = Outflow_Restoration (Stenting ∪ Bypass) ∪ Valve_Reconstruction (Valvuloplasty ∪ Transplant ∪ Neovalve)

explanation.intuition: When the deep venous highway is blocked or its one-way doors (valves) are destroyed, blood cannot efficiently return from the leg. Deep reconstruction either clears the blockage (stenting, bypass) or rebuilds the doors (valve surgery) to restore normal circulation.
explanation.key_insight: Endovascular stenting has revolutionized iliofemoral obstruction treatment, but valve reconstruction remains challenging with limited durability. The key is proper patient selection: stenting for obstruction, valve surgery only for isolated reflux without obstruction in select patients.
explanation.technical_details: Outflow reconstruction addresses chronic iliofemoral obstruction through dedicated venous stenting (14-24mm) or open bypass (Palma cross-femoral, May-Husni femoropopliteal). Valve reconstruction addresses isolated deep reflux through internal valvuloplasty (tightening redundant cusps), external valvuloplasty (cuff or sling), valve segment transplantation (brachial or axillary), or neovalve creation. Combined procedures address obstruction plus reflux.
common_misconceptions: Misconception: Deep venous reconstruction is routinely performed. Reality: Most patients are managed with compression and superficial intervention; deep reconstruction is reserved for severe, refractory disease.
Misconception: Valve transplant restores normal function. Reality: Transplanted valves have limited durability; 5-year competence is 50-60%.
Misconception: Open bypass is obsolete. Reality: Palma procedure remains valuable for unilateral iliofemoral occlusion when stenting fails.

valve_incompetence: Primary deep venous reflux with ulceration
Isolated deep reflux after superficial ablation
Severe reflux in axial deep veins

iliofemoral_stenting.technique: IVUS-guided deployment of dedicated venous stents (14-24mm)
iliofemoral_stenting.outcomes: 85-95% patency at 5 years for non-thrombotic; 70-80% for post-thrombotic
iliofemoral_stenting.details: See DVD-004 for comprehensive stenting details

palma_procedure.indication: Unilateral iliofemoral occlusion with healthy contralateral limb
palma_procedure.av_fistula: Often added distally to enhance patency
palma_procedure.outcomes: 70-80% patency at 5 years with AV fistula

may_husni_bypass.outcomes: Limited data, reserved for select cases

internal_valvuloplasty.indication: Redundant, stretched but intact valve cusps
internal_valvuloplasty.technique: Venotomy, direct suture plication of cusps
internal_valvuloplasty.outcomes: 70% competence at 5 years in primary disease

external_valvuloplasty.technique: External cuff or sling to reduce annular diameter

neovalve_creation.technique: Intussusception of vein wall to create valve-like structure

postoperative_care: Anticoagulation (warfarin or DOAC) for 6-12 months minimum
presentation: Non-healing venous ulcer despite superficial treatment
diagnosis: CT or MR venography for anatomy
treatment: Address superficial reflux before deep intervention
Consider bypass if stenting fails or not feasible
Valve surgery for isolated reflux in select patients

definition.@value: Surgical and endovascular procedures to restore deep venous outflow or valve competence in patients with severe post-thrombotic syndrome or primary deep venous insufficiency refractory to conservative management.

sources.title: Rutherford's Vascular Surgery and Endovascular Therapy
SVS/AVF Guidelines on Management of Chronic Venous Disease

learning_objectives: Identify candidates for deep venous reconstruction
Compare endovascular and open reconstruction options
Describe valve surgery techniques and outcomes
clinical_pearls: Iliofemoral stenting is first-line for chronic obstruction - see DVD-004
Palma procedure requires healthy contralateral saphenous vein and patent iliocaval segment
Valve surgery has limited durability: 50-60% competence at 5 years
Always optimize superficial and perforator treatment before deep intervention
Combined obstruction + reflux is treated with stenting first, then reassess for valve surgery
